You may deduct the amount you paid for medical and dental insurance and for long-term care insurance that qualifies you and your family.

You may deduct the cost of preparing the appropriate parts of your tax returns related to your business as a self-employed person or as a legal employee. You may also deduct the amount you pay or that is paid to you for the resolution of tax deficiencies related to your business as a self-employed person or as a legal employee.

For tax purposes, a non-U.S. citizen is an individual who is not a U.S. citizen. Non-U.S. citizens are classified as non-resident aliens and resident aliens. This publication helps you determine your status and provides the information you need to file a U.S. tax return. Resident aliens are generally taxed as U.S. citizens on worldwide income. Non-resident aliens are taxed only on U.S. source income and on certain income related to U.S. trade or business activities.

Most treaties require that the non-resident alien be a resident of the treaty country for the year in which the benefit is claimed. However, some treaties require that the non-resident alien be a resident of the treaty country immediately before entering the United States in order to be eligible for the benefit.

Foreign non-resident income is total income subject to tax limitation under a tax treaty. Treaty income includes, for example, dividends from U.S. sources that are subject to a treaty rate of tax not exceeding 15%. Non-treaty income is total income of a foreign non-resident that is not subject to tax limitation under a tax treaty. To calculate the tax on income items subject to a reduced treaty rate, calculate the tax on each individual income item by applying the reduced treaty rate to the amount of each individual income item. To calculate the tax on income items subject to a reduced treaty rate, calculate the tax on the income by applying a 30% rate or a differential rate, depending on whether the income is from U.S. sources or is substantially connected to U.S. business transactions or operations. Your tax liability is the total of the tax on treaty income and the tax on non-treaty income. However, it is not more than the tax liability that would be calculated if the treaty were not in effect.

In the following paragraph, we briefly describe the tax treaty provisions relating to personal service income, remittances, scholarships, grants, and capital gains income. The conditions for claiming an exception vary from one treaty to another. For detailed information on the conditions of a particular treaty, download the entire text of the U.S. tax treaties from IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z(English). Legal explanations for many of the treaties are also available on this website. Also, see Publication 901(English). Treaty benefits also include dividends, interest, rents, royalties, retirement and pension distributions. Such types of income may be exempt from U.S. taxes or subject to reduced tax rates. For more information, see Publication 901(English).

The majority of the tax treaties under which you are temporarily resident in the United States as a non-resident alien of a treaty country and who are entitled to the benefits of the treaty country's tie-breaker rules (see Chapter 1) may be eligible to be exempt from United States tax on a portion or all of their personal services income if they meet the requirements of the treaty provisions applicable to them.
Some tax treaties include other requirements, such as other maximum stay periods. For details, see Publication 901 (English).

Some tax treaties include a “independent personal services” clause. This clause allows residents of the treaty country to be exempt from U.S. taxes on income from independent contracting or self-employment if they did not spend more than a certain number of days in the U.S. and did not have a regular fixed place of business in the U.S.

According to various tax treaties, a non-resident foreign teacher or professor who visits the United States temporarily for the primary purpose of teaching at a college or other accredited educational institution is exempt from United States income tax on the compensation received for teaching after arriving in the United States for the first 2-3 years. Additionally, various treaties provide exemptions for research. Generally, a teacher or professor must be primarily engaged in teaching, lecturing, or research in the United States. The individual must devote the majority of his or her time to these duties. A teacher or professor's regular duties include regular scheduled classroom work, such as teaching, demonstrations, and other student participation activities, as well as informal seminars or other informal groups where ideas are presented, such as participation in experiments.

All treaties contain provisions exempting the income of certain officials of foreign governments. However, there are differences among the treaties as to who is eligible for these benefits. Under most treaties, a person who is not a national of the country of residence or a citizen of a foreign country is not eligible. Officials of a foreign government should consult the relevant treaty to determine whether they are eligible for the benefits. Chapter 10 contains information about officials of foreign governments.

Under certain tax treaties, payments received by students, trainees, and interns for research and maintenance purposes are exempt from tax. Also, under certain treaties, the amount of scholarships, grants, and limited allowances received by students, trainees, and interns are exempt from tax. If you are a non-resident alien who entered the United States as a resident alien but are now a non-resident alien, the treaty exemption may still apply. See Nonresident Alien Students, Trainees, Interns, Teachers, Professors, and Researchers after Residence.

Most treaties provide for the exemption of gains from the sale and exchange of personal property. Generally, gains from the sale and exchange of real property located in the United States are taxable.

Most tax treaties contain a “savings clause” that preserves or “saves” the U.S. right to tax U.S. citizens and residents as if the treaty were ineffective. As a result, resident foreigners generally are not eligible for treaty benefits. However, some tax treaties contain exceptions to the savings clause that allow resident foreigners to claim continuing treaty benefits. Some exceptions to the savings clause apply to all resident foreigners (e.g., under the U.S.—China treaty). Other exceptions apply only to U.S. legal residents (i.e., those who hold a green card). In some cases, because of the exemption from U.S. taxation under the treaty, you may not need to file Form 1040 or 1040-SR to report income. However, if income was reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042, Form 1099, or another information return, you must report that income on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (e.g., line 1a for wages or salary reported in box 1 of Form W-2). On Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8z, enter the amount of treaty benefit claimed. On line 8z, enter “Exempt income,” the treaty country, and the treaty provision that provides the exemption. If the exemption is instead a reduced rate of tax on income, enter the amount of tax calculated at the reduced rate, the treaty country, and the treaty provision that allows the reduced rate of tax to be applied. Attach a statement to Form 1040 or 1040-SR that describes the reduced rate of tax and the treaty provision that allows the reduced rate of tax to be applied. On line 16 of Form 1040 or 1040-SR, enter the tax. Check box 3 and enter “Tax from attached statement.”

Under the Canada-Germany Income Tax Treaty, a U.S. resident who receives Social Security benefits from Canada or Germany will be treated as having received the benefits under the Social Security Act for U.S. income tax purposes. If you receive Social Security benefits from Canada or Germany, you must determine the taxable amount of the benefits and report it on line 6b of Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. You do not need to file Form 8833 to report the benefits.

In order to claim tax treaty exemption for scholarship, fellowship, and grant income, and for compensation for personal services rendered, received from abroad for research and study, you must generally be a non-resident alien student, trainee, intern, teacher, professor, or researcher. Upon becoming a resident alien, you generally can no longer claim exemption from U.S. income tax under the treaty. However, if you were a non-resident alien when you entered the United States but are now a U.S. resident alien for tax purposes and the treaty contains a saving clause (as explained above) that provides exemption and you meet the other treaty exemption requirements (as explained below, in the section on treaty exemption claims), the treaty exemption will continue to apply. As explained in Chapter 1, even if you are a non-resident alien who has elected to file a joint return, the same rule applies. If you are eligible for an exception to the treaty provisions, you can file Form W-9 with a statement from your payer stating that you are not a U.S. citizen or resident alien and that you are not subject to backup withholding because you are exempt from backup withholding.

In certain cases, if the income is exempt from U.S. tax under the treaty, you do not need to report it on Form 1040 or 1040-SR. However, if the income is reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042, Form 1099, or any other information return, you must report it on Form 1040 or 1040-SR in the appropriate line. (For example, in the case of Form W-2, Box 1, report the amount on line 1a). On Schedule 1 (Form 1040), enter the amount of the treaty benefit claimed on line 8z in the bracket. “Exempt income,” the treaty country, and the treaty provision under which the exemption is granted.

If there is one or more tax exemption provisions in the Vienna Convention or in a bilateral consular agreement, you should determine whether your salary qualifies for the tax exemption under these provisions. If you are a U.S. citizen or resident, you generally do not qualify for the tax exemption under the Vienna Convention or a bilateral consular agreement. For more information on the Vienna Convention and bilateral consular agreements, contact the Office of Foreign Missions, U.S. Department of State, at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

The following requirements must be met for a foreign government employee to be eligible for a tax exemption under the Vienna Convention, a bilateral consular agreement, or a tax treaty. The exemption applies only to current foreign government employees and not to former employees. Retirement benefits received by a former foreign government employee who is living in the United States are not eligible for the exemption. The exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The determination of whether you are an employee or an independent contractor is based on the common law rules. Please refer to Publication 1779 (English) and Publication 15-A (English). If you are employed by a regulated commercial entity or if your services are primarily related to the commercial activities of a foreign government (in or outside the United States), your income is not eligible for the exemption under the United States tax law. A regulated commercial entity is a commercial entity that is 50 percent (0.50) or more owned by a foreign government and is engaged in commercial activities in or outside the United States.

Many international organizations have established agreements that exempt your salary from US income tax. If you are employed by an international organization in the US, you should first check whether the international agreement that established the organization includes such a provision and whether you are eligible for it. Generally, such provisions do not exempt the salaries of US citizens and residents.

If your international organization is not established under an international treaty that includes tax exemption provisions and you are not (or are a U.S. citizen but also a Filipino national), you may also be exempt from U.S. income tax under the U.S. tax code. To determine whether you qualify for this exemption, see the rules for foreign nationals who maintain their immigration status (legal permanent residency) in the United States. This exemption applies only to current employees of the international organization and does not apply to former employees. Retirement annuities received by former employees of the international organization are not included in this exemption. This exemption does not apply to independent contractors. The determination of whether you are an employee or an independent contractor is made under the common law rules. See Publication 1779 (English) and Publication 15-A (English). To claim the exemption, you must be able to demonstrate that you meet the requirements of either the international organization treaty or the U.S. tax code. If so, you will need to know the number of the international organization treaty tax exemption provision and the number of the executive order that designated the organization as an international organization.

If you sign the waiver provision in Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (USCIS Form I-508) to maintain your lawful permanent resident status (Green Card), you will no longer be eligible for the tax-free treatment under the US tax code. If you are an employee of a foreign government or an international organization, you must provide evidence that you did not sign and submit USCIS Form I-508, such as a written statement from USCIS.

Foreign residents and non-resident aliens are taxed differently. Foreign residents are generally taxed the same as US citizens. Non-resident aliens are taxed on the basis of the source of their income and whether their income is actually derived from transactions or business in the US. The discussion below will help you determine whether your income received during the tax year was actually derived from transactions or business in the US and how it is taxed.

Foreign residents are generally taxed in the same way as US citizens. This means that worldwide income is subject to US tax and must be reported on a US tax return. Foreign residents' income is taxed at the same progressive rates as US citizens. Foreign residents use the tax tables and work sheets included in the instructions for Form 1040 to calculate their US tax liability.

The difference between the two categories is that income that is actually connected is taxed at a progressive rate after allowed deductions. This is the same rate applied to US citizens and resident aliens. Income that is not actually connected is taxed at a flat rate of 30% (or a lower treaty rate). If you were previously a US citizen or resident alien, this rule does not apply to you. See the end of this section on the tax on giving up citizenship.

The following discussion will help you determine whether you are engaged in a trade or business in the United States.

If you perform personal services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are considered to be engaged in U.S. trade or business. Certain payments made by a foreign employer to a nonresident alien are not included in gross income. For more information, see Foreign employers in chapter 3.

If you were a nonimmigrant “F,” “J,” “M,” or “Q” visa holder in the United States and did not engage in a trade or business, and if you participated in a scholarship or fellowship program described in Section 1441(b) and had taxable income from such a program, you are treated as having engaged in a trade or business in the United States. The taxable portion of a scholarship or fellowship grant from a U.S. source is treated as income from a trade or business that is substantially connected with the activities in the United States.

If your only U.S. business activity is trading in stocks, securities, or commodities through a U.S. resident broker or agent, or hedging transactions involving such trading (including futures trading), you are not engaged in U.S. business or trading. In the case of stock and securities trading, this applies to nonresident aliens who trade in stocks and securities through a broker or dealer, as well as to those who trade in futures. In the case of commodity trading, this generally applies to commodities traded on organized exchanges and transactions arising from such exchanges.

You are considered to have renounced your U.S. citizenship on the earliest of the following dates: 1. The date you renounced your U.S. citizenship at a U.S. embassy or consulate (if confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of nationality after your voluntary renunciation). 2. The date you submitted to the Department of State a signed U.S. voluntary renunciation of nationality form (if confirmed by the issuance of a certificate of loss of nationality after your voluntary renunciation). 3. The date the Department of State issued a certificate of loss of nationality. 4. The date a U.S. court canceled your naturalization certificate.

You are considered to have renounced your lawful permanent resident status in the United States on the earliest of the following dates: 1. The date on which you filed Form I-407 with the U.S. Consulate or Immigration Service to renounce your lawful permanent resident status. 2. The date of the final administrative action applying to you under the Immigration and Nationality Act to renounce your lawful permanent resident status (or, if you appealed such action, the date of the final judicial order relating to such action). 3. The date of the final administrative order of deportation under the Immigration and Nationality Act to which you are subject. 4. If you were a dual resident of the United States and a country with which the United States has a tax treaty, the date on which you became a resident for tax purposes under the provisions of the treaty. For more information on dual residents, see Chapter 1, Tax Treaty Provisions.

If you abandon your citizenship after June 16, 2008, you will be considered an abandoned citizen and the following conditions will apply to you under Section 877A. 1. If you abandoned your citizenship or terminated your residence in 2024, and the average annual net income during the five-year period ending on the date of abandonment or termination of residence was more than $201,000, 2. If you had a net worth of more than $2 million on the date of abandonment or termination of residence, 3. If you cannot prove that you complied with your U.S. federal tax obligations during the five-year period before the date of abandonment or termination of residence by filing Form 8854.

The tax on the realized capital gains (or losses) from the sale of assets at fair market value on the day before the citizenship is renounced applies to income tax in the year of the renunciation of citizenship. This applies to most types of asset holdings on the day of the renunciation of citizenship or the day of the termination of residence. However, see the following exception. The gain from the deemed sale is to be considered in the year in which the deemed sale occurred, regardless of the provisions of other United States tax laws. The loss from the deemed sale is to be considered within the limits specified in the provisions of the United States tax laws. However, Section 1091 (on the non-allowance of losses from wash sales of stocks and securities) does not apply. If you renounced citizenship or terminated residence in 2024, you must subtract $866,000 from your net income, if any, otherwise included in your income.

However, items (1) and (3) are subject to withholding. For item (2), you are treated as having received the accumulated benefit as of the date of your renunciation of citizenship on a present value basis. For item (4), you are treated as having received a distribution of the total value of the account as of the day before the date of your renunciation of citizenship. For more information, see Form 8854 instructions and Notice 2009-85.

After you have determined your alien status and the source of your income, the next step is to determine whether and how to tax your income. The information in this chapter on resident aliens is not as comprehensive as that on nonresident aliens. The information on filing tax returns for resident aliens is generally the same as for U.S. citizens, so resident aliens should obtain the same publications, forms, and instructions as U.S. citizens. If you were a nonresident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year, see chapter 6, Double-Status Aliens.

비거주 외국인은 거주 외국인이 청구할 수 있는 항목별 공제의 일부를 청구할 수 있습니다. 하지만, 비거주 외국인의 소득이 미국에서 거래 또는 사업에 실질적으로 연결 있는 경우에만 항목별 공제를 청구할 수 있습니다. 스케줄 A에서 청구할 수 있는 항목별 공제의 총액의 한도가 있을 수 있습니다. 스케줄 A (양식 1040)의 지침 또는 양식 1040-NR의 지침(영어)에서 스케줄 A (양식 1040–NR)—항목별 공제에 대한 지침 을 참고하십시오.

If you receive income from U.S. trades or businesses that are actually connected to your foreign trades or businesses, you may be able to deduct certain itemized deductions. You can generally include only deductions and losses that are properly allocated to U.S. trades or businesses. You can't include deductions and losses related to income that is not actually connected to U.S. trades or businesses. However, you can deduct certain charitable contributions, losses from disasters and thefts, even if they are not actually connected to U.S. trades or businesses. To claim itemized deductions, use Schedule A (Form 1040-NR). For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English).

Special rules apply to students and trainees who are eligible for the benefits of Section 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty. If you did not claim itemized deductions, you may claim the standard deduction. Use Table 5-1 to calculate the standard deduction for 2024. If you are married and your spouse files a separate return and chooses itemized deductions, you may not choose the standard deduction.

If you are a U.S.-India income tax treaty student or trainee (refer to IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters(English)) affected by a specific disaster declared by the federal government in 2024, you may be able to choose to increase your standard deduction by the amount of your disaster-related personal loss on your 2024 tax return. Use Schedule 5-1 to calculate your 2024 standard deduction. For more information about disaster-related personal loss deductions, refer to Form 4684(English) and its instructions.

You can deduct state and local income taxes paid on income from U.S. sources and on income from a business you operate in the U.S. The total deduction is limited to $10,000 ($5,000 for a single return) combined. If you received a refund or credit for taxes paid in a prior year, do not deduct that amount. Instead, if you claimed a deduction for the taxes in a prior year and the deduction reduced your tax, you must include the refund or credit as income in the year you received it. For more information on how to figure the amount to include, see Publication 525 (English), Recoveries (Refunds).

Direct gifts to foreign organizations are not deductible. However, gifts to U.S. organizations that control the use of funds or to foreign organizations that are U.S. organizations' foreign branches are deductible. Under a limited number of tax conventions, gifts to foreign charitable organizations may be deductible. For more information, see Publication 526 (English).

You may be able to claim a loss on your tax return for damage or theft of property. You may be able to claim a loss for damage or theft of nonbusiness property that is not related to your trade or business if the damage or theft was caused by a federal government-declared disaster. Your property must be located in the United States at the time of the damage or theft. You can claim a loss only in the year you discover the theft. Use Form 4684 and its instructions to figure the amount of the loss and theft you can claim. For more information, see Publication 547.

Non-U.S. citizens file their tax returns using the same rules that apply to U.S. citizens. They report their taxable income and any tax withheld on Form 1040, Schedule 1. The following are some of the deductions you may be able to claim.

You may be able to claim a foreign tax credit for taxes you paid on income from a foreign country or from a foreign source. You cannot claim a credit for taxes you paid on income that is excluded from U.S. income. If you claim a credit for taxes you paid on income from a foreign country, you generally must file Form 1116 with your Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication 514 (English).

If you paid someone to care for your child under age 13 or a dependent relative who is disabled, or for your disabled spouse, and the reason was so that you could work or look for work, you may be able to claim this credit. For more information, see Form 2441 (English) and Publication 503 (English).
If you are 65 or older, or are permanently and totally disabled, you may be eligible for this credit. For more information, see Publication 524 (English) and Schedule R (Form 1040).

If you paid qualified education expenses for yourself, your spouse, or your dependents, you may be eligible for a tax credit. There are two education tax credits: the American Opportunity Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit. You cannot claim these credits if you file a joint return. To figure these credits, use Form 8863. For more information, see Publication 970 (English). Nonresident aliens should see Nonresident Aliens - Education Credits later.

Other Dependent Care Tax Credit is for people who have dependents but are not eligible for the Child Tax Credit. A qualifying dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or U.S. resident alien. They must have a valid SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued before the filing deadline for the 2024 tax year (including any filing extensions).

EIC or the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is a benefit for lower and middle income workers. To qualify for EIC, you must work for someone or have income from owning and operating a business or farm and meet the basic rules. You must also meet the additional rules for eligible children who are not working or meet the rules for eligible children with children. EIC can reduce the amount of taxes you owe and may also give you a refund. For more information, visit IRS.gov/EIC. If your (or your spouse's, if you file a joint return) child does not have a valid Social Security Number (SSN) issued before the filing deadline for the 2024 tax return (including any extensions), you cannot claim the Earned Income Tax Credit on your original 2024 tax return or an amended tax return. Also, if your child does not have a valid SSN issued before the filing deadline for the 2024 tax return or before (including any extensions), you cannot count that child as an eligible child for the child tax credit calculation on your original 2024 tax return or an amended tax return. If you (or your spouse or eligible child) are eligible for federal assistance benefits and your Social Security card has “Not Valid for Employment” written on it and has a number issued, you cannot claim EIC. Examples of federal assistance benefits include Medicaid. If the card has this writing and your immigration status has changed so that you are now a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, you can request a new Social Security card without this writing from the SSA.
Foreign residents may claim a portion of the same tax deduction. They may report the tax paid, or the tax that was deemed to have been paid or withheld from their income.
If you have received income that is actually connected to the income, you are eligible for a tax deduction. You may also be eligible for some of the following deductions.

If you received income from sources outside the United States that is related to your U.S. trade or business, you may be able to claim a foreign tax credit for the income tax paid on that income. If you do not have income from sources outside the United States that is related to your U.S. trade or business, you cannot claim a foreign tax credit for taxes paid on income from sources outside the United States. If you are a citizen or resident of a foreign country or U.S. territory solely because of your foreign or U.S. territory income tax liability, you generally cannot claim a foreign tax credit for taxes paid on U.S. source income. If you claim a foreign tax credit, you generally must attach Form 1116 to your tax return. For more information, see Publication 514 (English).

You may be able to claim a child and dependent care credit if you paid someone to care for your child or dependent relative who is under 13 years old or is disabled, or if you paid someone to care for your disabled spouse. You may also be able to claim this credit if you paid someone to care for your spouse while you were looking for work or while you were working. The definition of who is eligible for this credit is in Publication 503 (English). If you are a married nonresident alien, you may be able to claim this credit if you file a joint return with your U.S. citizen or resident spouse, or if you are a married person who does not live with your spouse and you meet the joint filing requirements (see Publication 503 (English) for the joint filing test). The total amount of child and dependent care expenses that you can claim as a credit for any tax year cannot be more than the amount of your U.S. income for that tax year.

Adoptee children are always treated as your own children. Adoptee children include legally placed children for adoption purposes. If the taxpayer does not have a valid SSN or ITIN issued by the IRS by the filing deadline for the 2024 return or before (including any extension), the taxpayer cannot claim the child tax credit for that child on the original 2024 tax return or an amended tax return. If your child does not have a valid SSN issued by the employer by the filing deadline for the 2024 return (including any extension), the taxpayer cannot claim the child tax credit for that child. However, the taxpayer may be able to claim the other dependent credit for that child. Refer to Other Dependent Credit discussed below. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and the instructions to figure the child tax credit.

If you have a dependent who is not eligible for the child tax credit, you may be eligible for the other dependent credit. This is an $500 non-refundable tax credit per eligible person. An eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, or a resident alien. Refer to the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English). To claim the credit for other dependents, the taxpayer's dependent must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN issued on or before the filing deadline day of the 2024 tax return (including any extended deadline) or the day before. Only non-U.S. citizens, residents of Canada, Mexico, or the Republic of Korea, or individuals who are eligible under the income tax treaty with India, 21(2), who are students or trainees in business training in India, are eligible for the other dependent credit.

If you were a nonresident alien for any part of the tax year, you generally cannot claim the earned income tax credit. However, as discussed in the section on nonresident alien spouse, if you are married and file a joint return with a U.S. citizen or resident alien spouse, you may be eligible for the credit. If you and your spouse do not have a valid Social Security Number (SSN) issued to you before the filing deadline for the tax year (including any extensions), you cannot claim the credit on your original or amended tax return for that tax year. If your child does not have a valid SSN issued to him or her before the filing deadline for the tax year (including any extensions), you cannot count him or her as a qualifying child for the child credit on your original or amended tax return for that tax year. If you (or your spouse or qualifying child) are eligible for federal assistance benefits and your Social Security card has “Not Valid for Employment” written on it and the number is issued, you cannot claim the EIC. Federal assistance benefits include Medicaid. If your immigration status has changed so that you are now a U.S. citizen or legal permanent resident, you can request SSA to issue a new Social Security card without the “Not Valid for Employment” writing on it.
You can claim the tax withheld during the tax year as a US tax payment. You claim this on lines 25a and 25g of form 1040-NR. The tax withheld reduces the amount of tax you must pay on form 1040-NR.

If you have more than one employer, you may be able to claim a credit for the amount of Social Security tax withheld in excess of the maximum Social Security tax. For more information, see Social Security and Medicare Tax.

Your employer is required to withhold an additional Medicare tax of 0.9% (0.009) on Medicare-eligible compensation of $200,000 or more in 2024. If you do not owe the additional Medicare tax, you can claim a credit for the additional Medicare tax withheld on your tax return by filing Form 8959.

If you are a shareholder of a mutual fund (or other regulated investment company (RIC) or real estate investment trust (REIT)), you may be able to claim a deduction for the company's paid tax on your share of the long-term capital gains. You will receive information about Form 2439, which you must attach to your tax return.

You can claim the tax withheld from your investment and other FDAP income as paid tax. Fixed or determinable income includes interest, dividends, rents, royalties that you are not substantively connected to. Wages or salaries may be fixed or determinable income, but generally they are subject to the above discussed withholding. Tax on fixed or determinable income is withheld at 30% or a lower treaty rate.

If you are a partner in a foreign partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the partnership income. The partnership will send you a Form 8805 showing the withheld tax. A partnership that is treated as a publicly traded partnership may also withhold tax on the actual distribution of the partnership's effectively connected income. In this case, the partnership will send you a Form 1042-S. Report the withheld tax as tax paid on line 25e or 25g of Form 1040-NR.
Please note that the translation must be in English.

Taxes withheld on the disposition of U.S. real property interests (deemed gained from the disposition of U.S. real property interests) are reportable as income on your return. Refer to Section 4 above for real property gains or losses. The purchaser will provide you with a Form 8288-A statement of withheld amount. Report the withheld amount as income on line 25f of your Form 1040-NR.

When you fill out your tax return, you should pay special attention to the correct amount of tax withheld as shown in the information documents. The following table lists some of the more common information documents and shows where to find the tax withheld.

If you are a non-resident alien for the entire tax year for which you are filing, you are generally taxed as a resident alien. File Form 1040 or 1040-SR to report all income from sources within and without the United States. However, you may exclude the following income from your report. You are considered a non-resident alien for purposes of reporting income. For example, you are not allowed a standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot claim a dependent if the person is not a U.S. citizen or national. There are also limits on deductions and credits allowed to non-resident aliens. See Deductions, Deductions and Credits, and Filing for more information.

If you are a resident of Puerto Rico for the entire year, you can exclude all Puerto Rico source income from your total income. (Not the amount earned as a government employee or for a government agency). File your return by the due date based on the calendar year. If you had no income subject to withholding in 2024, you must file your return and pay your tax by June 16, 2025. You must also pay your first estimated tax for 2025 by June 16, 2025. You cannot file a joint return or pay joint estimated tax. If you are married to a nonresident alien and file a joint return, see Nonresident Alien Spouse as a Resident for more information. If you earned income subject to withholding, your due date to file your U.S. income tax return is April 15, 2025. You must pay your first estimated tax for 2025 by April 15, 2025. For more information about withholding and estimated tax, see Form 8.

If you are a resident of American Samoa for the entire year, you can exclude American Samoa source income from your gross income (not the amount earned as an employee of the U.S. Government or its instrumentality). For purposes of the exception, an employee of the Government of American Samoa is not considered an employee of the U.S. Government or its instrumentality. For more information, see Form 4563 and Publication 570 (English).

You must compute your income based on the tax year, which is called the annual accounting year. If you have not established a tax year, your tax year will be the previous year. A previous year is a continuous 12-month period ending on December 31. If you previously established a regular tax year (a 12-month period ending on the last day of a month or a 52 or 53-week period ending on December 31) and are considered a U.S. resident in any previous year, you are considered a U.S. resident for part of the tax year in which you are a U.S. resident.

The taxpayer identification number (TIN) must be included on all tax returns, statements, and other tax-related forms. For individuals, this is the social security number (SSN). If you do not have an SSN or are not eligible for an SSN, you must apply for an individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN). An employer identification number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in business as a sole proprietor, have employees, or have a qualified retirement plan.

Generally, as a permanent resident of the United States or an alien authorized to work in the United States under the law of immigration, you can get a Social Security Number (SSN). If you do not have an SSN, contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) to see if you are eligible. For more information, visit SSA.gov or call 1–800–772–1213 (for the hearing impaired or deaf, call TTY number 1–800–325–0778).

If you already have an ITIN, you can enter it in the SSN field on your tax return. If you do not have an ITIN or are not eligible for an SSN, you must apply for an ITIN. The specific steps to apply for an ITIN are explained in Form W-7 and the instructions. If you are eligible for an ITIN and your application is complete, you will usually receive a TIN from the IRS within 7 weeks. If you do not receive an ITIN or any other communication after 7 weeks, call the IRS recipient line at 800-829-1040 if you are in the U.S. or 267-941-1000 (not a toll-free number) if you are outside the U.S. ITINs are for tax purposes only. This number cannot be used for social security benefits or to change your employment or immigration status under U.S. law. If you are a non-U.S. citizen who is required to provide a TIN and is not eligible for an SSN, you must file Form W-7 to claim the allowed tax benefits and to be eligible for a TIN. The instructions and IRS.gov/ITIN have additional information about applying for an ITIN.

Some ITINs must be renewed. If you have not filed a federal tax return for tax years 2021, 2022, or 2023 at least once, your ITIN will expire at the end of 2024 and you will need to renew it to file a tax return for tax year 2024. You do not need to renew your ITIN if you do not need to file a federal tax return. To renew your ITIN, go to IRS.gov/FormW7 and use Form W-7 and its instructions. For more information, visit IRS.gov/ITIN. ITINs issued before 2013 are expired and you will need to renew them if you need to file a tax return for tax year 2024. If you have previously submitted a renewal application and it was approved, you do not need to renew again unless you have not used your ITIN at least once in a federal tax return for tax years 2021, 2022, or 2023.

A married non-resident alien who is not a U.S. citizen and is not a resident of the United States is required to use the married individual tax table or the married individual tax work sheet to determine the tax on income from U.S. sources or on business income when filing a joint return.

Form 1040-NR is used by non-resident aliens and foreign estates or trusts to determine tax on income effectively connected with a U.S. trade or business. The tax rate schedule W must be used for Form 1040NR.

You must report all income subject to taxation as set forth in the rules of Chapter 2, 3, and 4. For resident aliens, this includes income from all sources, both domestic and foreign. For non-resident aliens, this includes income from transactions or business that are effectively connected with the U.S. (subject to a different tax rate) and income from sources that are not effectively connected with the U.S. (subject to a fixed 30% or lower treaty tax rate).

Foreign residents and non-resident aliens can claim similar deductions on their US tax returns. However, non-resident aliens can generally only claim deductions for income that is effectively connected with their US trade or business.

You may claim deductions for your net income from sources other than the U.S. You may not claim deductions for income from sources other than the U.S. that are related to your business activities. The exceptions to this rule, which are discussed later, are that you may claim deductions for income from sources other than the U.S. up to the limit of your net income from sources other than the U.S.

You may deduct all ordinary and necessary business expenses incurred in carrying on a trade or business to the extent that they are connected with income derived from the trade or business. For more information, see Business Expense Deductions (PDF)

If you paid interest on a qualified student loan in 2024, you may be able to deduct up to $2,500 of the interest you paid. Generally, if you qualify for all tests, you can claim the deduction. Claim it on line 21 of Schedule 1 (form 1040). Attach Schedule 1 (form 1040) to form 1040-NR. For instructions on how to figure the deduction, see form 1040-NR, instructions (English). For more information, see Publication 970 (English).

If you have income from U.S. trades or businesses that is not effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business, you may be able to deduct up to 20% of the income from trades or businesses that are not effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business. Additionally, you may be able to deduct up to 20% of the income from qualified REIT dividends and qualified partnership (QPF) income. For more information, see line 13a of the instructions for Form 1040-NR (English). For more information about the deduction for income from trades or businesses that are not effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and its schedules, and the instructions for those forms and schedules.
Any losses incurred from transactions entered into for profit but not offset by insurance, etc., are only deductible to the extent they are related to income from U.S. trade or business.

If you were a qualified educator in 2024, you can deduct up to $300 of your qualified education expenses paid or incurred during 2024 for specific job development courses, books, supplies (other than health or physical education supplies used in physical education), computer equipment (including related software and services), and other materials and supplies used in the course of teaching. For more information, see the instructions for your tax return. Qualified expenses include amounts paid or incurred in 2024 for personal protective equipment and other supplies used to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

If you made traditional IRA contributions in 2024, you may be eligible to claim the IRA deduction. However, you must have earned income that is effectively connected with the conduct of a U.S. trade or business. You must file Form 5498 by June 2, 2024, to prove your 2024 IRA contributions. If you are covered by a retirement plan (including a 401(k)) through your job or self-employment, your IRA deduction may be reduced or eliminated. However, even if you are not eligible to claim the deduction, you can still make non-deductible contributions to your traditional IRA. If you made non-deductible contributions to your traditional IRA in 2024, you must report this on Form 8606. For more information, see Publication 590-A (English).

The price of the government-provided board and care services is not included in your income because it is for the purpose of following the orders of the command for a change of station. Similarly, amounts received for relocation allowance (DLA), temporary lodging expenses, temporary lodging allowance, or relocation housing allowance are not included in your income. For more information, see Publication 3 (English).

You must include all interest income that you received or that was deposited to your account during the tax year. Do not subtract any penalty for early withdrawal from the interest income. However, if the interest income was related to U.S. business or transactions during the tax year, you may deduct the penalty for early withdrawal from financial institution from line 17 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040). File Schedule 1 (Form 1040) with Form 1040-NR.

If you do not provide or provide an incorrect Social Security Number (SSN), Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN), or Adoptee Taxpayer Identification Number (ATIN) for your dependents in the Dependent section of your tax return, certain tax benefits may be denied. Refer to the previous identification number.

If you are a resident alien, your qualifying dependents include your qualifying child or qualifying relative. To qualify as a qualifying child, you must meet all five tests. To qualify as a qualifying relative, you must meet all four tests. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040. If you don't provide the SSN, ITIN, or ATIN of a qualifying dependent, or if you provide an incorrect number, you may not be able to claim certain tax benefits. See previous identification number.

If you are a resident alien in Mexico or Canada, or a U.S. citizen, you may claim each of your dependents who meet certain tests. A resident alien in Mexico or Canada, or a U.S. citizen, must use the same rules to determine dependents as a U.S. citizen. See Publication 501 (English).

Non-U.S. citizens who are residents of the Republic of Korea (except U.S. Government employees) may claim a qualifying dependent as their child. In addition to the rules for determining a qualifying dependent that are the same as for U.S. citizens, under the tax treaty between the United States and the Republic of Korea, the child of a non-U.S. citizen must have lived in the United States for part of the tax year in which the non-U.S. citizen is a resident.
Students and trainees who are eligible under Section 21(2) of the US-India Income Tax Treaty are eligible to claim their dependents, provided they meet the same eligibility criteria as US citizens.

If you were a resident alien and a non-resident alien in the same year, you have a dual-status tax year. Dual status does not mean citizenship. It means only that you are a U.S. tax resident. The rules for determining your U.S. income tax for a dual-status tax year are different for the periods you were a U.S. resident and for the periods you were a nonresident alien. The most common dual-status tax year is the year you entered and the year you left. See Foreign Person with Dual Status. If you are married and choose to be treated as a nonresident alien for purposes of the foreign earned income exclusion, this chapter's rules do not apply to you for the year you are treated as a nonresident alien.

If you are a resident alien on the last day of the tax year and file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by April 15 of the following year (see the tips below). If you file your income on a basis other than a calendar year, you must file your return by the 15th day of the 4th month following the end of your tax year. In either case, file your return to the address for dual-status aliens on the back of the instructions for Form 1040. If you are a nonresident alien on the last day of the tax year and file your income on a calendar year basis and receive income subject to withholding, you must file your return by April 15 of the following year. If you file your income on a basis other than a calendar year, you must file your return by the 15th day of the 4th month following the end of your tax year. If you do not receive income subject to withholding and file your income on a calendar year basis, you must file your return by June 15 of the following year. As a dual-status alien, the tax forms you must file in the United States depend on whether you are a resident alien or a nonresident alien for the tax year in question.

For the tax year in which you were a resident alien and were a U.S. resident on the last day of the tax year, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. File a “Dual-Status Return” on the top of your income tax return. Attach a statement to your income tax return to show your income for the period of time you were a nonresident alien during the tax year. Form 1040-NR may be used as a statement, but clearly mark it as a “Dual-Status Statement” on the top.

If you are a resident for the tax year in which you gave up residency and are a dual-status filer at the end of the tax year, you must file Form 1040-NR. File a “Dual-Status Return” on the top of your tax return. Attach a statement to your tax return showing your income for the period of time you were a resident in the tax year. You can use Form 1040-NR as a statement, but clearly mark it as a “Dual-Status Statement” on the top. If you gave up citizenship or terminated residency in 2024, you must file Form 8854 with your tax return. For more information, see Chapter 4 on giving up citizenship.

Foreign residents must file Form 1040 or 1040-SR, as instructed in the instructions for Form 1040 and 1040-SR. The filing deadline and tax payment period are April 15 of the following year in which you file your tax return (see the previous tip). Under the Immigration and Nationality Act, you are required to file a tax return, but if you fail to file, you may be considered to have renounced your permanent residence and may lose your permanent resident status.

If you want the following, you must file it. Refunds for over-withholding, overpayment, or claims for deductions or credits. For example, if you have income from real property that is treated as effectively connected income even though you did not conduct business in the United States (as discussed in Chapter 4), you must file a timely, true, and accurate return for that income to be allowed to claim the deductions or credits allowed for it. For information about the definition of timely, see the timing of filing for deductions and credits for filing timing.

Even if you left the United States and filed Form 1040-C at the time of departure, you must still file an annual U.S. income tax return. If you are married and you and your spouse are required to file a return, you must file a separate return.

If you are an employee and receive income subject to US income tax withholding, you generally must file a tax return by the fourth month after the end of the tax year. For 2024, this is by April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee and receive income subject to US income tax withholding, you generally must file a tax return by the sixth month after the end of the tax year. For 2024, this is by June 16, 2025.

The following allowed deductions are not subject to this time requirement. Deductions for taxes withheld on gasoline and special fuels. Deductions for taxes paid on mutual funds (or other RICs) or REITs' withheld long-term capital gains.

If you fail to include your SSN or ITIN or another person's SSN or ITIN on a return, statement, or other document, you may be subject to a penalty of $50 for each failure. If you fail to disclose your SSN or ITIN to another person on a return, statement, or other document, you may be subject to a penalty of $50 for each failure. The term “negligence” includes the failure to make a reasonable effort to comply with the tax laws and the failure to exercise ordinary and reasonable care in preparing the tax return. Negligence also includes the failure to keep books and records. In this section, we discuss how to pay your U.S. income tax on the income you earned or received during the year. Generally, federal income tax is a pay-as-you-go tax. There are two types of pay-as-you-go tax methods. 1. Withholding. If you are an employee, your employer will probably withhold income tax from your paycheck. Tax is also withheld from certain other types of income. For example, pension, bonus, fees, gambling winnings, etc. Each case, the withheld amount is paid to the Internal Revenue Service on your behalf. 2. Estimated tax. If you do not pay tax through withholding or if you do not pay enough tax through withholding, you may have to pay estimated tax. Business owners generally pay tax in this way. You may also have to pay estimated tax if you receive income such as dividends, interest, rent, royalties, etc. Estimated tax is used for income tax, self-employment tax, and alternative minimum tax.

You must inform your employer whether you are a resident alien or a nonresident alien so that your employer can withhold the correct amount of tax from your wages. If you are a resident alien, you must submit Form W-9 or a similar form to your employer. Under these rules, if you are a nonresident alien, you must submit Form 8233 or Form W–8BEN to your employer to prove that you are a nonresident, or submit Form W-4 to prove that your wages are subject to the lower differential rate of withholding tax applicable to resident aliens or U.S. citizens. If you are a resident alien and received income other than wages from U.S. sources (dividends, royalties, etc.), you must submit Form W-9 or a similar statement to the withholding agent (usually your employer) to prevent the agent from withholding tax at the 30% (or lower agreed rate) rate on that income. If you received this type of income as a nonresident alien, you must submit Form W-8BEN to the withholding agent to prevent the agent from withholding tax at the 30% (or lower agreed rate) rate on that income. However, if the income was substantially connected to U.S. trade or business, instead submit Form W–8ECI.

The following discussion generally applies only to non-resident aliens. The tax on income from employment of a resident alien is the same as that on income from employment of a U.S. citizen. Income from employment of a non-resident alien as a employee is subject to withholding at a different rate from that on income from employment of a U.S. citizen or a resident alien. Therefore, your compensation is subject to withholding at the different rate, unless it is legally excluded or exempt by agreement.

Tips received for services performed in the current tax year in the United States are taxable. Include this in your taxable income. Additionally, if you received tips of $20 or more per month from one employer, you are subject to the tip income tax rate.

If you worked as an employee in the United States, you must generally pay Social Security and Medicare taxes on most of the income you earned. The taxes you pay contribute to your Social Security benefits. Social Security insurance provides retirement, survivor, and disability benefits and Medicare health insurance benefits to individuals who meet certain eligibility requirements. Generally, Social Security taxes apply to the first $168,600 of taxable compensation earned in the United States in 2024. All taxable compensation is subject to Medicare taxes. Your employer must withhold these taxes from each of your paychecks. Your employer must withhold these taxes even if it does not expect you to be eligible for Social Security or Medicare benefits. If you have one or more jobs and your combined taxable compensation for 2024 exceeds $10,453.20, you may be able to claim a refund of excess Social Security taxes on your income tax return. If your employer withheld more than $10,453.20, you cannot claim a refund of that amount. Request a refund from your employer. If your employer does not refund the excess, you can file a refund claim using Form 843. Generally, both employees and employers, whether U.S. citizens or foreign residents, are subject to Social Security and Medicare taxes on compensation earned as an employee in the United States. In limited circumstances, these taxes may apply to compensation earned outside the United States. Your employer should tell you whether Social Security and Medicare taxes were withheld from your pay. If you have no taxes to pay, you cannot file a voluntary tax return.

There is no special rule for non-resident aliens for the additional Medicare tax. If there is a portion of the income that is subject to Medicare tax, the excess over the limit for the income subject to Medicare tax, may also be subject to the additional Medicare tax. Your employer is required to withhold 0.9% (0.009) of the Medicare tax on income over $200,000 for Medicare benefits or RRTA benefits. If you plan to file a joint return and you expect your spouse's personal income to be less than $200,000 but your total income and self-employment income will be more than $250,000, you may request additional withholding on Form W-4 or pay estimated tax. If you file Form 1040-NR, if your total income and self-employment income is $125,000 for married filing separately (see the married separate box on page 1 of Form 1040-NR), $200,000 for married filing jointly (see the married joint box on page 1 of Form 1040-NR), or $250,000 for unmarried or qualified surviving spouse (see the unmarried or qualified surviving spouse box on page 1 of Form 1040-NR), you must pay the additional Medicare tax. To determine whether you must pay the additional Medicare tax, see Form 8959 and its instructions. For more information about the additional Medicare tax, visit IRS.gov/ADMTfaqs (English). Self-employed individuals may also be subject to the additional Medicare tax. See Self-employment income for more information.

If you have to pay self-employment taxes, you can deduct part of the taxes you paid from your adjusted gross income when you calculate your self-employment taxes. This deduction is calculated on Schedule SE (Form 1040).

The United States has generally concluded social security agreements with foreign countries to adjust social security insurance and taxes for employees who have worked in one or more countries during all or part of their careers. Under these agreements, double insurance and double contributions (taxes) for the same occupation are eliminated. These agreements generally specify that social security taxes (including self-employment taxes) are to be paid only in one country. For a list of current international social security agreements, visit SSA.gov/international/status.html. Additional agreements with countries will be posted on this website when they are implemented. For more information on international social security agreements, visit SSA.gov/international/totalization_agreements.html.

Generally under this agreement, social security taxes apply only in the country where you worked. However, if you were temporarily sent to the United States by the same employer to work and your wages are generally subject to both countries' social security taxes, most agreements allow your wages to be covered by the social security system of the country where you were sent. Under the agreement, your wages are exempt from U.S. social security taxes (including Medicare taxes) only if you or your employer request a specific certificate from the appropriate foreign country's agency. Usually, this agency will be the one from which you or your employer have paid the foreign social security taxes. The agency can tell you what information is needed to issue the certificate. Your employer must keep a copy of the certificate to prove that you are exempt from U.S. social security taxes because you were sent to the United States temporarily. Only wages received after the effective date of the agreement or after the date of receipt of the certificate can be exempt from U.S. social security taxes.

Most agreements provide that self-employed individuals are covered by the social security system of the country in which they reside. However, under some agreements, if you temporarily move your business activities to the United States or from the United States, you may be exempt from United States self-employment taxes. If you believe that your self-employment income is only subject to United States self-employment taxes and is exempt from foreign social security taxes, you can request a certification letter from the SSA. Refer to the notes above for the link. This letter will prove that you are exempt from foreign social security taxes. To establish that your self-employment income is only subject to foreign social security taxes and not to United States self-employment taxes, you should request a certification letter from the appropriate foreign agency.

The three types of losses are all referred to as federal declared disasters, but the requirements for each loss are different. A federal declared disaster is a disaster declared by the President of the United States under the Stafford Act to ensure federal government support. A federal declared disaster includes (a) a major disaster declaration, or (b) an emergency declaration under the Stafford Act.

Disaster losses are losses that result from a federal declared disaster and are located in a designated disaster area. Disaster losses must occur in a county that is eligible for public or private assistance (or both). Disaster losses are not limited to personal use assets, but can also include personal business or income-producing assets, as well as corporations, S corporations, and partnerships. If you have suffered a disaster loss, you may be able to claim a disaster loss deduction, which can be carried forward to a prior tax year. Refer to the section on disaster losses later in this publication.

Disaster losses include personal injury and theft of personal property caused by the following: 2016 Stafford Act Section 401 declared major disaster, Hurricane Harvey, Tropical Storm Harvey, Hurricane Irma, Hurricane Maria, 2017 and 2018 California wildfires declared major disaster by the President under Stafford Act Section 401, which occurred prior to January 1, 2019 and did not continue beyond January 19, 2020 (excluding disaster relief for the 2018 California wildfires that occurred prior to January 1, 2019 and were mitigated by pre-mitigation actions), and any major disaster declared by the President on or after January 1, 2019 and before February 10, 2025. In addition, the disaster must have occurred on or after December 28, 2019 and before December 12, 2024, and must have terminated prior to January 11, 2025.

If you are an individual, you can only claim a loss from a federal declared disaster (FDIC) for the tax year in which the disaster occurred. An individual use property is a property that is not a business or income-producing property. If you have a personal loss (not from a federal declared disaster) that occurs before January 1, 2018, but you do not suffer a loss until after January 1, 2018, you cannot claim a personal loss. The way to report income depends on whether the asset is a business asset, an income-generating asset, or a personal use asset.

Individuals report losses from income-producing assets on Schedule A (Form 1040). They report the total of gains and losses from business and income-producing assets on Form 4797. If Form 4797 is not required to be filed separately, report the net loss or gain on the line identified on Form 4797 as Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 4. On that line, enter “Form 4684”. Partnerships and S corporations should refer to the instructions for Form 4684 to determine where to report these gains and losses.

If business and income-producing assets result in a loss, that loss is combined with business income to arrive at a net loss. File Form 4797 to report the net loss or gain. If you do not need to file Form 4797 separately, report the net loss or gain on the line identified on Form 4797 as “Form 4684.” If you are an individual filing Form 1040 or 1040-SR, report the net loss or gain on line 4 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040), or line 4 of Schedule 1A (Form 1040-SR). If you are a partnership or S corporation, refer to Form 4684 to determine where to report these profits and losses.

If you have a depreciable asset that has been damaged or stolen and has been held for more than one year, you may be able to deduct all or part of the depreciation allowed or allowed to be taken on the asset. In the event of a disaster or theft, the amount of insurance or other compensation received, minus any deductible, must be subtracted from the basis of the asset. This is the adjusted basis. In the event of a loss from disaster or theft, the deduction for that year may exceed the income for that year. You do not need to be engaged in a trade or business to have a loss from disaster or theft. For more information, see the instructions for Form 172.

The personal use property limitation for taxable years 2018 through 2025 does not apply to income-producing property losses, such as Ponzi-type investment plan losses.
For personal use assets, determine the amount of loss that can be claimed by applying the deduction limits discussed later.

In the event of a disaster, you will not be able to claim any insurance proceeds to cover your living expenses. You will not be able to use your principal residence because of the disaster. The government will not allow you to access your principal residence because of the risk of a disaster.

Loans used to restore or replace assets that are the subject of a loss claim are not considered to reduce the loss. If you have a canceled (forgiven) federal loan, check the canceled federal loan section later in this publication.

If you claim a loss deduction and later receive a larger refund than expected, you may have to include part of the refund as income in the year you receive it. However, if the deduction you claimed in the year you filed your return did not reduce your tax for that year, you do not have to include part of the refund as income. You do not recalculate your tax for the year you claimed the deduction. See Publication 525, Tax Recovery for more information about including additional refund as income.
In the event that you receive the same amount of refund as you expected to receive later, you do not need to include the refund in your income and you cannot claim any additional loss.

There are two ways to deduct inventory losses due to damage or theft. One is to deduct the loss through the increase in inventory cost by properly reporting the beginning inventory and the inventory at the end of the year. Do not re-claim the loss as damage or theft. If you deduct the loss through the increase in inventory cost, include all insurance or other reimbursements in total income. The other is to deduct the loss individually. If you deduct the loss individually, adjust down the beginning inventory or purchase cost to remove inventory items affected by inventory cost. Reduce the loss by the amount of reimbursements received. Do not include reimbursements in total income.

The recovery of stolen property is the recovery of property that was stolen and later recovered. If you have already taken a theft loss deduction for the property, you must use the adjusted basis (later explained) or the decrease in FMV from the time of the theft to the time of recovery to refigure the loss. Use this amount to refigure the total loss for the year in which the loss was taken. If the refigured loss is less than the loss taken, you generally must report the difference as income for the year in which the property was recovered. However, report only the amount that gives you a tax benefit. For more information, see Publication 525, ’Tax Guide to U.S. Tax Law’, at ’Recovery of Stolen Property’.

The safe harbor method described in the 2018-08 R.P. is available for determining the amount of disaster and theft loss for personal use residential real estate and personal property. The safe harbor method described in the 2018-08 R.P. is not mandatory. If you use the safe harbor method described in the 2018-08 R.P. and meet the requirements, the IRS will not challenge your determination.

Using the replacement cost shelter method, you can determine the FMV of personal property located in a disaster area just before a disaster is declared by the federal government. To use the replacement cost shelter method, first determine the current cost of replacing the personal property with new property, and then reduce that amount by 10% each year you own the property. Refer to IRS Publication 2018-08, Personal Property Appraisal. You must use the replacement cost shelter method for all personal property, except for certain exceptions specified in IRS Publication 2018-08. These shelters have additional rules and exceptions. For more information, refer to IRS Publication 2018-08.

You must subtract from the loss determined by the shelter method the value of repairs provided free of charge by a third party (e.g. repairs performed by a volunteer or by work for which a donation has been made). You must also subtract from the loss the amount of insurance, reimbursement or other compensation.
