Using the Repair Cost Escrow Method, you can determine the decrease in FMV of a personal use residential real property by using the lower of two repair estimates prepared by two separate and independent contractors. The estimates must itemize the cost of restoring the property to its condition immediately before the disaster occurred. The Repair Cost Escrow Method is limited to $20,000 of disaster loss.

The minimum repair cost method of disaster recovery allows you to determine the decrease in FMV of a residential real property based on a reasonable estimate of the repair costs required to restore the property to its condition prior to the disaster. You must keep records showing how you determined the amount of loss. The minimum repair cost method may be used for disaster losses of $5,000 or less.

Using the insurance refuge method, you can determine the decrease in the FMV of a residential real estate asset based on the expected loss shown in a report prepared by the owner or a flood insurance company. These reports must state the expected loss you incurred due to the damage or destruction of the asset.

In the event that losses incurred in a disaster-affected area are due to a disaster declared by the federal government, you may use the contractor refuge method or the disaster loan appraisal method. Under the contractor refuge method, you may use the contract price for repairs specified in the contract prepared by an independent, qualified contractor to determine the FMV decrease of your personal use residential real estate. You and the contractor must have signed a binding contract for this method to apply, and also, unless the contractor specifies the itemized cost of restoring your personal use residential real estate to its pre-disaster condition, this refuge method does not apply.

You can determine a decrease in the FMV of a residential real estate property for personal use by using an appraisal prepared for the purpose of obtaining a Federal Disaster Loan or a Federal Government Loan Guarantee, in accordance with the method of the Federal Disaster Loan Program for identifying expected losses due to a federally declared disaster.

Expenses incurred to protect assets from damage or theft are not included in the damage or theft loss. Expenses incurred to insure or repair your home against storm damage are not included in the loss. If the asset is a business asset, these expenses are deducted as business expenses. If you permanently improve an asset to protect it from damage or theft, add the improvement costs to the asset's cost basis. An example of this is the cost of a flood wall.
You cannot increase the basis of an asset or deduct business expenses for costs incurred in relation to eligible disaster relief payments (discussed in the next section on disaster losses).

Loss of asset value is not considered because it is caused by the area where damage to property has occurred or the area near it, or the area where damage to property may occur again. Only the loss of actual damage to property is considered. However, if the house is in a federal declared disaster area, refer to the disaster area loss later.

In 2010, you received property from a deceased person and, if the executor of the deceased person's estate made an election under Section 1022 using Form 8939, 'Amounts in increase in basis of property acquired from a deceased person', the special rule for basis would apply to the property. If the executor of the deceased person's estate made an election under Section 1022, the executor may choose to apply the adjusted deferred basis to the property acquired from the deceased person. For more information about the Section 1022 election, see Notice 2011-66, 2011-35 I.R.B. 184, available at IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#NOT-2011-66. For information about the Section 1022 election, see IRS.gov/irb/2011-35IRB#RP-2011-41, Revenue Procedure 2011-41, 2011-35 I.R.B. 188.

During the period of ownership of an asset, a variety of events may occur that will change the basis amount. The basis amount increases due to some events such as additional or permanent improvements to the asset. The basis amount decreases due to prior disaster losses and depreciation deductions, etc. The adjusted basis amount is the result of adding the increase to the basis amount and subtracting the decrease from the basis amount. For more information on determining the basis amount of an asset, see Publication 551.

You must determine the amount of loss from a disaster or theft after you determine the amount of loss from a disaster or theft. There are limitations on the amount of loss from personal-use property that can be deducted. For tax years 2018 through 2025, the loss from personal-use property from a disaster declared by the federal government is only deductible. The loss from personal-use property from a federal disaster declaration is subject to the later discussed $100 and 10% rule. The $100 and 10% rule is also summarized in Table 2. An exception to the rules is that the loss from personal-use property from a federal disaster declaration is limited to the loss from a federal disaster declaration, if you have personal disaster income in the tax year. In this case, you can reduce your personal disaster gain from a federal disaster declaration. Any excess gain is used to reduce the loss from a federal disaster declaration. The 10% rule applies to any remaining federal disaster loss. Loss from business assets and income-producing property is not subject to this rule. However, if the property used or rented for business was involved in a disaster or theft, the loss may be limited. Refer to Form 4684, Section B for instructions. If you have a loss from damage or theft of property used in a passive activity, refer to Form 8582, 'Limitations on Passive Activity Losses' and the instructions.
Generally, you must keep a separate record of the loss of each item stolen, damaged, or destroyed. However, there are special rules for property owned for personal use.

Personal assets are all assets other than real estate. In the event that personal assets are stolen, or there is a loss of life or destruction, you must identify the loss for each asset separately. Then add up these individual losses to calculate the total loss. Subtract $100 and 10% of AGI from the total loss to calculate the loss deduction.

In the event that both real estate and personal assets are involved in a disaster, you must determine the loss for each type of asset separately. However, you can only reduce the total loss by $100 once. Then, apply the 10% rule to determine the disaster loss deduction.

In the case of assets that are used partly for personal purposes and partly for business or income-generating purposes, you must calculate the loss from disaster or theft separately for the personal use portion and the business or income-generating portion. Since the two types of use result in two different types of loss, you must calculate each loss separately. When you calculate each loss, allocate the total cost or basis, the FMV before and after the disaster or theft, and any insurance or other reimbursements to the business and personal use assets. The $100 rule and the 10% rule apply only to the personal use portion of the asset in the case of a loss from disaster or theft.

If your principal residence is destroyed, you can generally exclude the gain from the sale or exchange of the property, just as you would if you sold or exchanged your home. You can exclude up to $250,000 of gain (up to $500,000 for married filing jointly). To qualify for this exclusion, you generally must have owned and used the property as your principal residence for at least 2 of the 5 years before the destruction date. For more information, see Publication 523. If you have a gain that exceeds the amount you can exclude but you buy a replacement property, you can postpone reporting the gain. See the next section for more information.

Generally, you must report income in the year you receive the payment. However, if you meet certain requirements and choose to defer reporting the income as described in the rules for deferring income in the following section, you do not need to report the income. For detailed instructions on how to report the income, see the instructions for reporting income later. If you have a loss from a disaster or theft of personal-use property (as described in the following section) and you choose to defer reporting income from another loss from personal-use property, do not consider the deferred income when you calculate the loss deduction. Refer to the 10% rule in the previous deduction limit.

If you receive compensation in the form of property or services that are similar to or related to the damaged or stolen property, you should not report a gain. Generally, the basis of the new property is the same as the adjusted basis of the property being replaced. If you receive money or other property as compensation, you generally must report a gain on the stolen or destroyed property. However, you may be able to delay reporting a gain if you purchase property that is similar to or related to the property you received as compensation, or if you use the stolen or damaged property within a specific replacement period later discussed. You may also choose to delay reporting a gain if you purchase the controlling interest (at least 80%) in a corporation that owns the property. See later in this publication for more information about the controlling interest of a corporation. If you have a gain on the damaged property, you may be able to delay reporting the gain if you use the compensation to restore the property. To delay reporting all gains, your replacement property must be at least equal to the amount of compensation you received. If the cost of the replacement property is less than the amount of compensation, you must include the unused portion of the compensation as income.

In the event that you pay a contractor in advance to replace an asset that has been damaged or stolen, the replacement asset will not be considered purchased until the replacement period has ended, unless the replacement is completed before the end of the replacement period. Refer to the replacement period later.

In the event that you receive a refund for damage to your principal residence that exceeds the amount of income excluded from your tax return due to the damage (referring to the previous principal residence damage in the income determination), you may postpone filing a tax return for excess income by purchasing a replacement asset for a similar or related service or use. In order to postpone filing a tax return for the total amount of excess income, the amount of the replacement asset must be at least the amount of income excluded from the damage. In addition, if you postpone filing a portion of the income under this rule, you are treated as having owned the damaged asset and used it as a principal residence during the period you owned the replacement asset and used it as a principal residence.

In the case of a disaster declared by the federal government, special rules apply to replacement assets related to damage or damage to the main residence (or household property) located in the disaster area. For details, refer to the realized gain from the main residence located in the disaster area.

In the event that a business or income-producing asset is damaged in a declared federal disaster area, any asset of the same type that is acquired for use in the business will be considered to be of a similar or related use to the damaged asset. The replacement asset does not need to be located in the federal disaster area. For more information, refer to Disaster Area Loss later.

If your principal residence (or contents of your principal residence) is located in a declared federal disaster area, the replacement period generally ends when the first tax year in which a portion of your gain is realized ends. See later for disaster area losses.

Extensions are usually limited to periods of one year or less. High market value or the scarcity of replacement assets does not constitute sufficient grounds for an extension. If the replacement asset is under construction and it can be completed within the replacement period, an extension may be granted.

You may postpone reporting your gain on your tax return for the year in which you report your choice. You have a gain if you receive insurance proceeds or other compensation for the loss. Only the partnership or corporation that owns the stolen or damaged property may elect to postpone reporting the gain.

In the case of acquiring a replacement asset before filing the return for the year in which the gain was realized, all the following items must also be included in the paperwork. Replacement asset. Deferred gain. Basis amount adjusted for deferred gain. All gains reported as income.

When you designate a qualified replacement asset on a tax return form, you cannot later replace it with another qualified replacement asset. The same is true if you acquire another asset during the replacement period. However, if you discover that the existing replacement asset is not a qualified replacement asset (during the replacement period), you can replace it with a new qualified replacement asset.

If the amount of insurance or reimbursement you receive is greater than the adjusted basis of the destroyed or stolen property, you have a gain from disaster or theft. You must include this gain in your income for the year you receive the reimbursement, unless you choose to postpone filing the return as described above.

Generally, you can only deduct a loss from a disaster that occurred in the tax year in which the disaster occurred. This is true even if you do not repair or replace the damaged property until the following year. (However, see the next paragraph for an exception regarding disaster losses.) You can deduct a loss from property stolen in the year you discover the theft. You can only deduct a loss if there is a reasonable expectation of recovery from the damage in the tax year in which the damage occurred. If part of a loss from a disaster or theft is not certain to be paid, do not deduct that part until you have a reasonable assurance that it will not be paid. The year in which you suffer the loss is the later tax year.

This section describes the special rules that apply to federal declared disaster area losses. It includes information on when you can claim the loss, how to claim the loss, how to handle disaster area residence, and how to postpone the filing deadline for your tax return. The phone number for the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) is also included. (See the reference to the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) for more information.) Disaster losses are losses from a federal declared disaster that are required to be supported by public or private assistance (or both) in an area. A federal declared disaster includes a major disaster or an emergency declared by the President under the Stafford Act. The list of areas that require public or private assistance (or both) under the Stafford Act is available at FEMA.gov/Disaster(English).

You must keep records to support your loss deduction. You do not need to attach these records to your amended return. If your records are destroyed or lost, you may need to reconstruct them. For information on reconstructing records after a natural disaster or casualty loss, go to IRS.gov/Newsroom/Reconstructing-Records-After-a-Natural-Disaster-or-Casualty-Loss or see Publication 3067, IRS Disaster Assistance-Federal Disaster Declarations(English).

If you have a copy of your tax return from last year, it is easier to complete Form 1040-X. If your tax return was prepared by a tax preparer, the tax preparer must provide you with a copy of the tax return. If not, you can get a copy by submitting Form 4506 to the IRS. There is a fee for each request. However, if you reside, work, or have a tax record in a state or area declared a disaster by the federal government, the fee is waived. Enter the name of the disaster on the upper right side of Form 4506 (e.g., “Tennessee Tropical Storm Helene”).
In accordance with the Stafford Act, a portion of the Federal Disaster Loan that is canceled is treated as a loss for repayment. The cancellation reduces the disaster loss deduction.

If you receive grants to help meet the cost of essential needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation, or burial expenses, do not include the grants as income under the Stafford Act. Do not deduct disaster losses or medical expenses to the extent that they are clearly reimbursed by the grants. If disaster losses are clearly reimbursed by the grants and you claimed a deduction for the disaster losses in the year you received the grants, refer to the reimbursement you received after the earlier loss deduction. The unemployment compensation you receive under the Stafford Act is taxable unemployment compensation.

In the event of a disaster, the loss of assets or destruction of assets resulting in a loss to the business may not be excluded from income as a result of the general welfare exclusion, as a gift, as a qualified disaster grant (as described below), or as a contribution to capital. However, the business may choose to defer the reporting of realized gains from the grant if the business purchases a qualified replacement asset within a specified period of time. Refer to the rules applicable to the deferral of previous gains to determine the applicable rules.

The disaster relief payments made under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (effective April 15, 2005) are not included in gross income. This is a payment made to you as the owner of the property to reduce the risk of future property damage. You cannot increase the basis of the property or claim a deduction or credit for any expenses incurred in connection with the payments.

Generally, when you sell or transfer an asset that is not your principal residence, you must recognize any gain or loss for tax purposes. You report the gain on your tax return for the year in which you recognize the gain, and you may deduct the loss from the gain in that year's tax return. (You cannot deduct a loss for a personal-use asset, except if the loss is the result of a disaster described in the instructions.) However, under the risk-reduction program, if you sell or transfer an asset to the federal government, a state or local government, or an Indian tribe government, you may choose to defer recognizing the gain for a specified period of time if you purchase a qualified replacement asset within that time. Refer to the instructions for the applicable rules regarding the deferral of prior gains.

The IRS can extend the filing deadlines for certain tax returns for taxpayers affected by a federal disaster. The IRS can extend the filing deadlines for income tax, special consumption tax, and employment tax returns, as well as for contributions to traditional or Roth IRAs. If a filing deadline is extended, the IRS will announce the tax filing deadline suspension for the area in question and publish any necessary guidance in the form of IRS Revenue Procedures, Notices, Announcements, or other IRS publications. You can check if a filing deadline has been suspended for your area by visiting IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief.

To get information from FEMA, visit DisasterAssistance.gov or call 800-621-3362. This number is only activated after a federal government-declared disaster. For those with hearing, speech or language disabilities, call 711 to be connected to a TRS counselor who will provide the 800-462-7585 number.

Generally, you must deduct disaster losses in a disaster year. However, if disaster losses are from a federal declared disaster in a public or private assistance (or both) required area, you can choose to deduct the losses on your return for the tax year before the disaster year or on an amended return for the disaster year. This choice treats the loss as if it occurred in the previous year. The list of areas where public or private assistance (or both) is required is on the FEMA web site at FEMA.gov/Disaster(English). You must choose to deduct disaster losses for the disaster year no later than six months after the filing deadline for the return for the year before the disaster year. If you are a calendar year taxpayer, you must amend your 2023 return to claim disaster losses for 2024 by October 15, 2025.

If you have already filed a return for the previous year, you can file an amended return to elect to claim a disaster loss for that year. An individual who files an amended return must use Form 1040-X to report the loss. (See later in this publication for information about reporting a loss on Form 1040-X.) To make this election, you must complete Part I of Section D of Form 4684 for the year of the disaster and attach it to your 2023 return or an amended return for that year. You must make the election for a disaster loss for a previous year no later than 6 months after the due date for filing your return for that year, or before that date. For individual taxpayers, the due date for making the election for a disaster loss for 2023 is October 15, 2025, if you file an original or amended return for 2023. For more information about how to claim a disaster loss on your return for the year of the disaster, see the instructions for Form 4684. If you claim a disaster loss on your return for the year of the disaster and elect to deduct a previous year's loss, you must file an amended return to deduct the previously claimed loss no later than the due date for filing your return for the year of the disaster, or before that date. If you elect to deduct a previous year's loss on your return for the year of the disaster, your tax for that year may be reduced, resulting in a refund or an increased refund.

Disaster losses that are eligible include losses from personal injury or theft of personal property due to the following causes: a major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act, Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Harvey, Hurricane Irma, Hurricane Maria, the 2017 and 2018 January California wildfires, and a major disaster declared by the President under Section 401 of the Stafford Act, between January 1, 2018 and January 19, 2020, and not continuing after January 19, 2020 (excluding pre-relief-provided 2018 January California wildfires), and a major disaster declared by the President between January 1, 2020 and February 10, 2025. Also, the disaster must have occurred on or after December 28, 2019, and before December 12, 2024, and end before January 11, 2025.

If your principal residence is located in a declared federal disaster area and you have incurred expenses to repair or replace your home, you may be able to postpone filing your return. If your principal residence (or its structure) is located in a disaster area, special rules apply to the replacement of assets related to the damage and destruction of your principal residence. For details, see the information on realized gains from previous disaster areas.

If your home is located in a federally declared disaster area, your state or local government may order you to demolish or move your home because it is no longer safe to live in. In this case, treat the loss of value as a disaster loss. Your state or local government must order you to demolish or move your home within 120 days of the area being declared a disaster area. Report the loss in the same way you report personal-use property disaster losses. (See prior loss reporting.) When determining the decrease in FMV, use the value of your home before it was demolished or moved as the FMV after the disaster.

To claim the EIC, you (and your spouse, if you file a joint return) must have a valid SSN by the filing deadline for 2024 (including any extensions). You may be eligible for a single EIC if you have one or more eligible children who meet the EIC requirements but do not have a valid SSN by the filing deadline (including any extensions). If your eligible child does not have a valid SSN by the filing deadline, see Schedule EIC to learn how to report Schedule EIC. An SSN is valid unless it was issued solely for the purpose of applying for or receiving a federal benefit, or it is not valid for employment. Federal benefits include Medicaid. If you, your spouse, or your child have a Social Security card that has “Not valid for employment” printed on it, and your, your spouse’s, or your child’s immigration status has changed to a U.S. citizen or permanent resident, request a new Social Security card without the “Not valid for employment” notation from the SSA.

If your SSN or your spouse's SSN is missing or inaccurate on your tax return, you may not be eligible for EIC. Form 2555, 'Foreign Income Exclusion', must be filed if you have foreign income. This form can be used to exclude foreign income from your gross income, or to claim a foreign housing deduction or exclusion. U.S. territories are not considered foreign. For more information, see Publication 54.

If your investment income is less than $11,600, you can claim the investment income tax offset. If your investment income is more than $11,600, you cannot claim this offset. Use Table 1 in this section to calculate your investment income.

To qualify, you must be working and have earned income, so this credit is called the “Earned Income Tax Credit” or EITC. If you are married and file a joint return, one or both spouses must be working and have earned income to qualify. If you are an employee, your earned income includes all taxable income you receive from your employer. Rule 15 has information to help you calculate your earned income. If you are self-employed or a statutory employee, you can determine your earned income by using the instructions in Form 1040, Schedule B.

All types of income are included in earned income. 1. Wages, salaries, tips, and other taxable employee compensation. Employee compensation is earned income only if it is taxable. Certain nontaxable employee benefits, such as nontaxable dependent care benefits and adoption assistance, are not income. Any individual may prepare or assist in preparing a tax return or refund claim, or appear as a witness on behalf of a taxpayer, or provide information to the IRS or an IRS officer at the request of the IRS or an IRS officer.

The following person may represent a designated taxpayer before the IRS if he or she can produce the appropriate identification documents. However, the following (1) person is an exception, and he or she must demonstrate that he or she has the authority to represent the taxpayer. 1. An individual. An individual may represent himself or herself before the IRS and is not required to submit a written statement of qualification and authority. 2. A family member. An individual may represent his or her immediate family members. An immediate family member includes the individual's spouse, children, parents, siblings, or siblings-in-law. 3. An officer. An officer of a corporation (including a parent corporation, subsidiary, or other affiliate), association, or organization group may represent the corporation, association, or organization group. An officer of a government department, agency, or instrumentality may represent the government department, agency, or instrumentality in the course of his or her official duties. 4. A partner. A general partner may represent a partnership before the IRS. 5. An employee. A regular employee may represent his or her employer. An employer may represent an individual, partnership, corporation (including a parent corporation, subsidiary, or other affiliate), association, trust, receiver, guardian, estate, organization group, government department, agency, or business instrumentality. 6. A trustee. A trustee (trustee, executor, personal representative, administrator, receiver, or guardian) may represent a taxpayer in a position other than that of a representative. For partnerships beginning after December 31, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 abolished the TEFRA partnership audit and litigation procedures and replaced them with a new centralized partnership audit regime, and eliminated the role of a “tax matters partner” and replaced it with a “partnership representative”. Under Treasury Regulation Section 301.9100-22T, certain partnerships may elect to apply the new regime to their partnership tax returns for tax years beginning after November 2, 2017 and before January 1, 2018.
If you have questions about taxes, need help preparing your tax return, or want to download free publications, forms, or instructions, visit IRS.gov to find out what's available right away.

The IRS ensures the safety of electronic payments using the latest encryption technology. You can make electronic payments using the IRS2Go app on your online, phone, or mobile device. Making electronic payments is faster and easier than sending a check or money order. You can make payments using one of the following options at IRS.gov/Payments. IRS Direct Pay: Pay individual tax bills or estimated tax payments directly from your checking or savings account without any additional cost. Credit or debit card: Choose an approved payment processor for online, phone, or mobile payments. Electronic Funds Withdrawal (EFW): Available only when filing federal taxes using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment System (EFTPS): This is the best option for businesses. You must register. Check or money order: Mail payment to the address listed on your notice or instructions. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at participating retail locations.

The Low Income Tax Clinic (LITC) is independent of the IRS. The LITC represents individuals with income at or below a certain level who need help with tax problems such as an IRS audit, filing a protest, or a tax collection dispute. The clinic can also provide information in other languages about taxpayers' rights and responsibilities to individuals who speak English as a second language. Services are provided free of charge or for a nominal fee. To find a clinic near you, visit TaxpayerAdvocate.IRS.gov/LITCmap or refer to IRS Publication 4134, List of Low Income Tax Clinics.

You can securely access your federal tax account information at IRS.gov/Account. Check the amount you owe or set up an online payment or payment agreement. Access your tax records online. Review your last 18 months of tax payments. Review the required identity verification process at IRS.gov/SecureAccess.

The fastest way to get your tax refund is to use direct deposit and e-file with IRS. Direct deposit is safe and electronically transfers your refund directly to your financial account. 8 out of 10 taxpayers use direct deposit to receive their refund. IRS processes 90% of refunds within 21 days.

The law has changed so that the IRS cannot process refunds for returns that properly claimed the EITC or ACTC before February 15, 2018. This applies to the entire refund, not just the portion of the refund related to these credits.
